scenario.name: Casey's Proactive Approach ‚Äî Following the 50/30/20 Rule
paragraphs: Casey earns $3,000/month and creates a monthly budget: $1,500 (50%) for needs including rent, utilities, groceries, and transportation. $900 (30%) for wants like dining out, entertainment, and hobbies. $600 (20%) for savings‚Äî$300 to emergency fund, $200 to retirement, $100 extra to student loans.
Casey tracks all expenses weekly using a budgeting app, automates savings transfers, and has built a 3-month emergency fund ($4,500) over the past year.

scenario.name: Taylor's Reactive Approach ‚Äî Same Income, Different Outcome
paragraphs: Taylor also earns $3,000/month but takes no systematic approach‚Äîpays bills as they arrive and spends freely until running low. Frequently overspends on dining out and entertainment, using credit cards to cover shortfalls.
Taylor has accumulated $4,000 in credit card debt at 18% interest, has no emergency savings, and misses the employer's 401(k) match. When unexpected expenses arise, more credit card debt follows.

main.title: Create Your 50/30/20 Budget
main.description: Using the interactive spreadsheet template, create a personal budget that allocates income according to the 50/30/20 rule. Scenario: You work part-time and earn $1,200/month. Create a budget that balances your needs, wants, and savings.

steps: Enter your monthly income ($1,200 or your actual income)
Calculate your 50/30/20 targets: $600 needs, $360 wants, $240 savings
Allocate specific expenses within each category
Review and adjust to ensure balance
Identify one area where you can reduce spending to increase savings

content.tagline: Budget Smart. Save First. Build Wealth.
